qas.question: Who did the Church of England split from?
At what time did the Church of England become independent?
Who headed the Anglican reforms in the middle of the 16th century?
The Church of England's reforms put it in the middle of what two traditions?
What liturgical forms in Anglicanism were considered unacceptable by many progressive Protestants?

context: The Church of England declared its independence from <a0_0>the Catholic Church<a0_0/> at the time of <a1_0>the Elizabethan Religious Settlement<a1_0/>. Many of the new Anglican formularies of the mid-16th century corresponded closely to those of contemporary Reformed tradition. These reforms were understood by one of those most responsible for them, the then <a2_0>Archbishop of Canterbury Thomas Cranmer<a2_0/>, as navigating a middle way between two of the emerging Protestant traditions, namely <a3_0>Lutheranism and Calvinism<a3_0/>. By the end of the century, the retention in Anglicanism of many <a4_0>traditional<a4_0/> liturgical forms and of the episcopate was already seen as unacceptable by those promoting the most developed Protestant principles.
